s.text: According to various postings on the Net, Hilfiger confessed on Oprah that if he had been able to predict the success of his clothing among "Chinamen and niggers," he would "never have made it so nice."
The second story has Hilfiger and Ralph Lauren appearing on CNN's Style With Elsa Klensch . Complimented on his success in selling his goods in the East, Lauren thanked his Asian customers.

According to various postings on the Net, Hilfiger confessed on Oprah that if he had been able to predict the success of his clothing among "Chinamen and niggers," he would "never have made it so nice."

According to various postings on the Net, Hilfiger confessed on Oprah that if he had been able to predict the success of his clothing among "Chinamen and niggers," he would "never have made it so nice."
The second story has Hilfiger and Ralph Lauren appearing on CNN's Style With Elsa Klensch . Complimented on his success in selling his goods in the East, Lauren thanked his Asian customers.

According to various postings on the Net, Hilfiger confessed on Oprah that if he had been able to predict the success of his clothing among "Chinamen and niggers," he would "never have made it so nice."
Hilfiger knew he had struck gold when he noticed black kids mixing the preppy look with sports gear on the street.

In the late 1980s, purported connections with the Ku Klux Klan so damaged the reputation of athletic-wear manufacturer Troop (whose name was rumored to be a Ku Klux Klan acronym for "To Rule Over Oppressed People") that it was forced into bankruptcy.
